results.title: Three To Go: Toula
results.creator_credit: Oliver Howes, Gil Brealey and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Part of a trilogy concerning the problems of young people in Australia. Toula is a girl in a Greek migrant family living in a Greek community in Sydney. She wants desperately to be a young, modern Australian, but she loves her parents and they demand a different way of life. In spite of family difference, gradually Toula and her brother establish a blend of Greek and Australian, bi-lingual and bi-social, which provides a certain amount of satisfaction for all concerned.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Oliver Howes, Gil Brealey and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Smokes and Lollies
results.creator_credit: Gillian Armstrong, Penny Chapman, South Australian Film Corporation and 1:1 Films
results.brief_description: First film in a longitudinal study of three Adelaide girls, aged thirteen and fourteen. They talk about their attitudes to sex and boys, pregnancy, abortion, marriage, school, parenthood and their careers. Their hopes and ambitions pose special questions for adults and young people alike. Edited by David Pulbrook; sound by Rod Pascoe and photographed by Tom Cowan.

results.title: Shine, Sir!
results.creator_credit: Kiwi Polish Company and The London Press Exchange
results.brief_description: An early advertising film, using animation, which promotes Australian made Kiwi boot and shoe polish and a fair capitalist system that allows for the initiative of youngsters. The ‘Imperial Hotel’ is left short staffed during World War I. Two young boys apply for the position of boot boys, but lament that they can’t clean boots. An Australian soldier, overhearing their conversation, offers each of them a tin of Kiwi boot polish which has impressive results and secures employment for them at the hotel.

results.title: Native Earth
results.creator_credit: John Heyer and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: A study of Australia’s responsibilities and administration issues in Papua New Guinea immediately after World War 2, with particular emphasis on the life and the needs of Papuans. Commentary by Peter Finch, researched by Catherine Duncan, script by Catherine Duncan, photography by Frank Bagnall, music by John Kay.

results.title: The Mount Hagen Show
results.creator_credit: Boris Cook and Information and Extension Services for the people of Papua New Guinea
results.brief_description: A mass gathering of highland tribes of diverse customs was indicative of the beginnings of unity and prosperity in Papua and New Guinea. This was the hope expressed by Lord de L’Isle when he declared the Mount Hagen Show open. But it is only the beginning. The response of brightly painted feather bedecked natives to the throb of drums; the incongruousness of their participation in bicycle racing and dodgem cars; the mixed expressions of curiosity and distrust amongst the native spectators, clearly show that the path to change is a long one.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Boris Cook and Information and Extension Services for the people of Papua New Guinea

results.title: Mexico 75: no place else in the world to be
results.creator_credit: Patricia Edgar and Centre for the Study of Educational Communication and Media, LaTrobe University
results.brief_description: A record of the International Women’s Conference in Mexico City in 1975. The film sets the Conference in the context of an underdeveloped country and discusses the relevance of the women’s movement to third world countries. There is special emphasis on the contribution of the Australian delegation.

results.title: Jim Serafim goes to School
results.creator_credit: David Roberts, Jan Sharp and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our multicultural society”.
A Greek child’s first day at school. Demonstrates the difficulties non-English speaking children and their parents have in their “new” country.
